awd_abstract_narration:
Surface waves are waves that propagate along a boundary or interface. They arise in many physical systems, such as water waves on the surface of the ocean and seismic surface waves generated by earthquakes. They also have a wide variety of technological applications, such as ultrasonic surface acoustic waves used in analog filters and surface plasmons used in optical and nano-optical devices. At lower intensities, effects of different waves add (waves superpose) and may be described by linear theories, but at higher intensities nonlinear effects become significant. Nonlinearity leads to qualitatively new phenomena, including wave interactions and the formation of singularities (such as shock waves). This project addresses the fundamental nonlinear dynamics of surface waves and their applications, especially nondispersive surface waves whose phase speed or frequency is independent of their wavelength. As a part of the project, graduate and undergraduate students will be trained through involvement in the research.

The project will carry out an asymptotic analysis of nonlinear surface waves in a variety of physical systems. Applications will be made to electromagnetic surface waves, or surface plasmons, waves on vorticity discontinuities and surface quasi-geostrophic fronts, plasma waves, and Rayleigh waves in elasticity. The resulting asymptotic equations are typically spatially nonlocal and quasilinear. These equations will be studied analytically and numerically, in particular with the aim of understanding the nonlinear focusing and possible formation and propagation of singularities in these surface waves. In addition, the project will study the diffraction and glancing Mach reflection of shock waves, together with related problems in transonic aerodynamics.

por.por_cntn:
Surface waves are waves that propagate along a boundary or interface. The most familiar examples are water waves on the surface of the ocean, but there are many other types of surface waves on fluid interfaces, some of which are described and analyzed in this project. The project is particularly concerned with the effects of nonlinearity on these waves, which may cause the waves to break or form singularities, such as shock waves in compressible fluids.

One system studied in the project concerns waves on an interface between two regions of an incompressible fluid flow with different constant vorticities. (The vorticity measures the local angular velocity of the fluid.) In a first approximation, the interface oscillates at a constant frequency proportional to the jump in the vorticities across the interface. The effects of nonlinearity on these waves is remarkably complex and the interface eventually breaks throwing off many, extremely thin filaments. One outcome of the project is a proof that the background oscillations of an interface with small slopes greatly delay the time it takes for the interface to break. This result also proves that the motion of the interface before it breaks is well-described by a Burgers-Hilbert equation, which provides a clear picture of the nonlinear dynamics of the interface.

A second, closely related, system studied in the project concerns waves on an interface between two different temperatures in surface quasi-geostropic flows. Quasi-geostrophic fluid flows are the primary flows in the atmosphere where the Coriolis force (due to the earth's rotation) and the pressure force almost balance. Surface quasi-geostrophic flows arise when quasi-geostrophic flows are confined to the surface of the earth. An outcome of the project is the careful derivation of equations for the propagation of waves along temperature discontinuities in surface quasi-geostrophic flows. These equations show that the waves exhibit an unusual type of logarithmic dispersion. Further outcomes include a proof that if the initial slope of the temperature discontinuity is sufficiently small then the interface never breaks.

Finally, the project studies the effect of spatially periodic temperature variations on the propagation of nonlinear sound waves in a compressible fluid. In some cases, this problem leads to equations that are similar to (but different from)  the Burgers-Hilbert equation that arises as a description of waves on vorticity discontinuities. One outcome of the project is the derivation of equations that describe the long-time behavior of the sound waves. These equations suggest that the temperature variations can greatly delay the formation of shocks in the sound waves.
